review.title: Distance Optimal Formation Control on Graphs with a Tight Convergence Time Guarantee
review.abstract: For the task of moving a set of indistinguishable agents on a connected graph with unit edge distance into an arbitrary target formation, free of collisions, we propose a fast distance optimal control algorithm that guides the agents into the desired formation. Moreover, we show that the algorithm also provides a tight convergence time guarantee (time optimality and distance optimality cannot be simultaneously satisfied). Our generic graph formulation allows the algorithm to be applied to scenarios such as grids with holes (modeling obstacles) in arbitrary dimensions. Simulations, available online, confirm our theoretical developments.

sections.heading: VI. CONCLUSION, FUTURE WORK, AND OPEN PROBLEMS
sections.text: In this paper, we show that the formation control of graphs, as defined in problem 1, has optimal distance solutions that can be efficiently calculated. In addition, the shortest paths can be planned to achieve a control policy with a narrow convergence time warranty. The calculation of the control policy can be carried out very efficiently. Two threads of future work are currently being researched, one of which is to decentralize the algorithm, ideally without a global clock and limited local communication. Another natural next step is to extend the results of graphs to continuous areas of work. There are many ways to do this. For example, we can place a graph structure on a Euclidean space via discretion (see e.g. Figure 8), which is not limited to grid structures. Given arbitrary initial and target formations, we can design controllers by aligning the initial and target formations at different levels first.
